items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: River and lake levels have now peaked on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water but the lake level remains high. The weather forecast is for a drier day and the lake level will continue to fall slowly. Areas still affected are locations around Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected. This message will be updated tomorrow, the 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have now fallen but remain high at the Llanymynech and Maesbrook river gauges. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. 
At 8am today the level at the Cae Howel guage was 4.1m and steady. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on Sunday 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have fallen at the Crew Green, Montford, Welsh Bridge and Buildwas gauges. 
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue the alert if necessary.    
Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on Sunday 02/01/22 or if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message: Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. Please stay aware in case further alerts are issued.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall over the past few days. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. River levels will remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 5pm on Sunday 02/01/22 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels are continuing to rise slowly on the River Dee. Flooding remains possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington throughout today (01/01/2022). The River Dee is expected to peak at lunchtime today at 8.2m and then begin to gradually drop. Please be aware that Townfield Lane could be cut off. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning (2/1/2022), or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Cheswick Green river gauge as a result of rainfall overnight and in the early hours of today, Sunday 02/01/2022
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, 02/01/2022. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Blythe between Cheswick Green and Blyth End.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the lower River Ray. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today (02/01/22), particularly in the Islip area. 
The forecast is for a dry morning, with showers that may be heavy at times during the afternoon. River levels in the Islip area are dropping slowly, but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. River levels upstream of Lower Arncott are now below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, some of which will be flooded. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message:
Waves and spray are forecast to overtop coastal frontages at The North Sea coast this afternoon. No property flooding is expected. Flooding is possible at The North Sea coast from Skipsea to Mappleton, in particular around Hornsea  between 03:30PM and 06:00PM on 02/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next five days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels remain high at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible through today, 1/1/22. Flooding may affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. River levels may fall slightly, later today, but are expected to remain high. River levels are forecast to rise again overnight in response to a band of rain passing through. Further rainfall is forecast for tomorrow, 2/1/22. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this time. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded, and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 tomorrow, 2/1/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high but are falling slowly on the River Thame. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue today (02/01/22) especially in areas around Dorchester. 
The forecast is for a dry morning, with showers that may be heavy at times during the afternoon. River levels in the Dorchester area are falling slowly but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels upstream of Stadhampton are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and be aware of debris and standing water that may remain on the floodplain. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but are falling steadily on the Lower Cherwell. Flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads remains possible today (02/01/22), especially in Thrupp and Kidlington areas. 
The forecast is for a dry morning, with showers that may be heavy at times during the afternoon. River levels around Thrupp and Kidlington are now within banks but will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days. Levels on the River Cherwell in the Oxford and Upper Heyford areas are below the flood risk threshold.
We are monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and be aware of debris and standing water that may remain on the floodplain. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels have fallen at the Sutton Gault river gauge and are high but steady at the Welney Causeway Guage. We expect flooding to affect the A1101 Wash Road at Welney.
This information is correct as of 07:30 on Sunday 2nd January. The causeway at Sutton Gault currently has 0 centimetres of water on the road, however some ponding and debris may remain. Lower sections of the Welney Causeway have flood water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
There are currently no issues on the Earith Causeway. 
Some further rainfall is forecast today, Sunday 2nd January, and throughout this week, therefore river levels may remain high or rise again over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Highways Teams, who will decide whether to close the roads.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  Flood water is receding from the causeway at Sutton Gault, however due to the uneven surface of the road deep puddles may be encountered. Further rainfall is forecast today, Sunday 2nd January, and into next week, therefore we will closely monitor the situation and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to slowly fall at the Bradford on Avon river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from today, 01/01/2022 and into tomorrow 02/01/2022.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.   
Further light rainfall is expected through Sunday and Monday.  We expect river levels to stop falling and show some slight response to the forecast rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Sunday, 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are falling.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster
River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels have now fallen below levels of concern on the River Ouse. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels have peaked on the River Ouse in York and levels are beginning to fall slowly. We will continue to monitor levels closely, however no further significant rainfall is expected and we expect levels to continue to recede.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 09:00 AM on 02/01/2022 with a forecast level of 1.31m. 
The Flood Alert will be in force for 2 hours before and after the high water time.
Forecasts suggests further Flood Alerts may need to be issued for tides on Sunday Evening and Monday Morning. We will re-issue this alert with further details should forecasts continue to suggest that it is needed.
Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon.
Our incident response staff have closed relevant flood gates and have been checking defences.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Please avoid flooded footpaths in the area.
This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Welney Causeway river gauge as a result of rainfall earlier this week. We expect flooding to affect The A1101 Wash Road at Welney. 
This information is correct as of 07:30 on 02/01/22. Lower sections of the causeway at have flood water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
This alert applies to WELNEY CAUSEWAY ONLY.
Some further rainfall is expected today, Sunday 2nd January and throughout this week, therefore whilst levels may fluctuate, they may remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the road.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 02/01/22, or as the situation changes.

Sunday morning's tide at 10:45 on 02/01/2022 is higher than normal, with strong South Westerly Force 5 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.23 m. The total forecast tide is 6.09 metres Chart Datum (3.04 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. At 23:15 on 02/01/2022‚ the tide is similar. We will issue further advice. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 14:00 on 02/01/2022

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message:
Waves and spray are forecast to overtop coastal frontages at The North Sea coast and Humber Estuary this afternoon. No property flooding is expected. Flooding is possible at The North Sea coast and Humber Estuary, in particular around Kilnsea and Spurn Point between 4:15PM and 7:15PM on 02/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next five days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.

Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message:
Waves and spray are forecast to overtop coastal frontages at The North Sea coast and Humber Estuary this afternoon. No property flooding is expected. Flooding is possible at The North Sea coast and Humber Estuary, in particular around Kilnsea and Spurn Point between 04:15PM and 07:15PM on 02/01/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next five days and as a result we may issue further alerts/warnings.

Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Plan driving routes to avoid coastal roads, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 09:00 PM on 02/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.74mAOD at 13:45 on 02/01/22 and 4.74mAOD at 02:15 on 03/01/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 113 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 08:00 on 03/01/22, or as the situation changes.
